constructs.name: perceived_engineering_competence
constructs.description: Subjective sense of being a capable, skilled engineer - the core feeling of 'I am good at this and belong here'

constructs.name: self_efficacy
constructs.description: Confidence in one's ability to successfully complete engineering tasks and solve complex technical problems

constructs.name: imposter_syndrome
constructs.description: Feeling like a fraud, that successes are due to luck, and persistent anxiety about being 'found out' as incompetent

constructs.name: task_performance
constructs.description: Perceived success in completing engineering work - code working, bugs fixed, problems solved, features shipped

constructs.name: external_validation
constructs.description: Recognition, positive feedback, and acknowledgment from peers, managers, code reviews, or users

constructs.name: technical_skill_growth
constructs.description: Sense of learning new skills, understanding new concepts, and expanding engineering knowledge over time

constructs.name: learning_engagement
constructs.description: Active engagement in learning activities - reading documentation, studying codebases, experimenting with new technologies

constructs.name: deliberate_practice
constructs.description: Intentional effort to improve skills through challenging work, feedback seeking, and reflection on mistakes

constructs.name: cognitive_clarity
constructs.description: Mental sharpness, ability to focus deeply, and capacity to think clearly about complex technical problems

constructs.name: emotional_wellbeing
constructs.description: Overall mood and emotional state - positive affect, energy, absence of anxiety or depressive symptoms

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and restorativeness of sleep - feeling rested and recovered

constructs.name: work_stress
constructs.description: Level of work-related stress, pressure, overwhelm, and demanding conditions

constructs.name: social_comparison
constructs.description: Tendency to compare oneself to peer engineers, often unfavorably to high performers

constructs.name: task_challenge_level
constructs.description: Difficulty and complexity of current engineering tasks relative to current ability level

constructs.name: psychological_safety
constructs.description: Feeling safe to take risks, ask questions, admit mistakes without fear of judgment or punishment

constructs.name: peer_support
constructs.description: Quality of support, help, collaboration, and positive interaction with engineering colleagues

constructs.name: professional_identity
constructs.description: Strength of identification with being an engineer as core to one's professional sense of self

constructs.name: autonomy
constructs.description: Sense of control and independence in how one approaches and completes engineering work

constructs.name: growth_orientation
constructs.description: Trait-level belief that abilities can be developed through effort and learning (growth mindset)

constructs.name: perfectionism
constructs.description: Trait-level tendency toward unrealistically high standards and harsh self-criticism when falling short

constructs.name: neuroticism
constructs.description: Trait-level tendency toward negative affect, anxiety, and self-doubt

constructs.name: years_of_experience
constructs.description: Total years of professional engineering experience

constructs.name: underrepresented_identity
constructs.description: Whether the person holds an underrepresented identity in engineering contexts (gender, race, etc.)

edges.description: Higher confidence in ability directly feeds subjective sense of competence
Imposter feelings directly undermine sense of being a competent engineer
Successfully completing engineering tasks provides direct evidence of competence
Recognition from others provides social proof of one's engineering competence
Sensing skill development over time builds perception of growing competence
Strong identification as engineer supports beliefs about one's engineering competence
Unfavorable comparisons with high-performing peers undermine competence perception
Having autonomy signals trust in one's competence and enables demonstrating capability
Mastery experiences are the strongest source of self-efficacy (Bandura)
Positive feedback from others builds confidence in one's abilities
Positive emotional state supports confident self-appraisal of capabilities
Learning new skills builds confidence in ability to handle challenges
Growth mindset supports resilient self-efficacy beliefs despite setbacks
Imposter feelings erode confidence in one's engineering abilities
Perfectionist standards make normal performance feel inadequate, fueling fraud feelings
Trait anxiety and self-doubt predispose to imposter experiences
Unfavorable comparisons with peers trigger feelings of being a fraud
Underrepresentation in engineering heightens feelings of not belonging
Low psychological safety amplifies fear of being exposed as incompetent
Higher self-efficacy provides buffer against imposter feelings
Mental sharpness enables better problem-solving and task execution
Greater accumulated skills enable better task performance
Confidence enables persistence and effective problem-solving approach
Task difficulty relative to ability affects likelihood of successful completion
Getting help and collaboration from peers improves task outcomes
High stress impairs cognitive performance on complex engineering tasks
Having control over approach enables more effective problem-solving
Good work performance leads to positive recognition from others
Psychologically safe environments encourage giving and receiving feedback
Supportive peers more readily provide acknowledgment and recognition
Active learning engagement leads to skill development
Intentional effortful practice builds engineering expertise
Appropriately challenging work stretches abilities and promotes growth
More experience provides foundation for faster skill acquisition
Feedback helps identify areas for improvement and confirms progress
Growth mindset motivates active engagement in learning
Feeling safe enables exploration and learning from mistakes
Mental energy and clarity enables engaging with new learning material
Confidence supports taking on challenging learning activities
Engagement with learning drives intentional practice efforts
Confidence motivates seeking out challenging practice opportunities
Positive feedback motivates continued effort to improve skills
Belief in growth through effort motivates deliberate practice
Good sleep is essential for cognitive function and mental sharpness
High stress impairs focus and clear thinking on complex problems
Positive mood supports clearer, more flexible thinking
Poor sleep impairs emotional regulation and lowers mood
Work stress depletes emotional resources and lowers wellbeing
Social support from colleagues improves emotional state
Trait neuroticism predisposes to lower baseline emotional wellbeing
Success at work improves mood and emotional state
Feeling competent at one's craft supports positive emotional state
Work stress disrupts sleep through rumination and physiological arousal
Poor mood and anxiety impair sleep quality
Excessively challenging tasks create stress and pressure
Low safety creates chronic stress about judgment and failure
Poor sleep reduces resilience to workplace stressors
Lack of control increases work stress (demand-control model)
Imposter anxiety creates chronic background stress and vigilance
Imposter feelings drive comparison-seeking to assess where one stands
Peer interactions provide opportunities for social comparison
Perfectionism drives comparison with highest achievers
Supportive collaborative peers create safer team environment
Receiving positive validation builds sense of safety to take risks
Safe environments encourage seeking and offering collegial support
Positive mood facilitates seeking and receiving support from peers
More experienced engineers are assigned more complex challenging work
Strong performance leads to being assigned more challenging tasks
Successful engineering work strengthens identity as engineer
Growing skills reinforce engineering professional identity
More experience solidifies professional identity as engineer
Being recognized as capable engineer reinforces professional identity
Safe environments enable being granted and exercising autonomy
Confidence leads to seeking and being granted more autonomy
More experienced engineers typically receive greater autonomy

indicators.name: advanced_topic_engagement
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if the search/visit involves advanced engineering concepts (cryptography, distributed systems, functional programming concepts like monads/applicatives/functors, consensus algorithms, PUFs, type theory, compilers). 0 if basic syntax lookup, simple how-to, or non-technical content.

indicators.name: proactive_exploration
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this entry shows proactive learning (reading documentation voluntarily, exploring concepts, researching technologies). 0 if reactive problem-solving (error messages, debugging, 'why doesn't X work', Stack Overflow troubleshooting).

indicators.name: challenging_topic_attempts
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if engaging with a challenging technical topic (learning new programming paradigm, cryptographic protocols, complex algorithms, category theory, formal methods). 0 for routine lookups or non-technical content.

indicators.name: deep_resource_engagement
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this entry shows depth (visiting detailed documentation, source code, academic papers, in-depth tutorials, sci-hub). 0 for surface-level resources (quick definitions, Wikipedia summaries, basic how-to).

indicators.name: imposter_doubt_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search explicitly relates to imposter syndrome, self-doubt, feeling like a fraud, 'am I good enough', 'do I belong in tech', questioning competence. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: basic_concept_lookup
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if looking up fundamental concepts typically known by experienced engineers (basic syntax, 'what is a variable', 'what is a function', 'define: loop', elementary programming terms). 0 for advanced topics or non-technical.

indicators.name: error_debugging_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to errors, debugging, stack traces, 'not working', 'fails', troubleshooting, or fixing broken code. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: solution_resource_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting a resource that provides solutions (accepted Stack Overflow answers, documentation examples, tutorial with working code, GitHub with solutions). 0 if still problem-searching or non-technical.

indicators.name: code_review_platform_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visit is to code review context (GitHub pull request pages, GitLab merge requests, Gerrit, code review notifications, PR feedback). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: professional_profile_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visit relates to professional recognition platforms (LinkedIn, Stack Overflow profile/reputation, personal tech blog stats, Hacker News submissions, Twitter/X tech presence). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: technical_domain
indicators.how_to_measure: Categorical: Assign primary technical domain. Options: 'functional_programming', 'cryptography', 'web_development', 'systems_programming', 'databases', 'devops', 'security', 'hardware', 'other_technical', 'non_technical'. Choose best fit for this entry.

indicators.name: learning_depth_level
indicators.how_to_measure: Ordinal 1-3: Rate depth of this resource. 1=surface (Wikipedia, simple definitions, basic tutorials). 2=moderate (official documentation, detailed tutorials, tech blogs). 3=deep (academic papers, source code, sci-hub, RFC specifications, advanced references).

indicators.name: learning_resource_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visit is to educational resource (documentation sites, tutorials, HaskellWiki, ArchWiki, official docs, educational videos, 'learn X', textbook content). 0 if not learning-focused.

indicators.name: conceptual_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if content explains concepts/theory (what monads are, how TLS works, why functional programming) vs 0 for purely procedural/how-to content or non-technical.

indicators.name: beyond_immediate_need
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if exploring concepts beyond immediate practical need (understanding theory behind tools, reading about algorithms not directly needed, studying language internals). 0 if directly task-focused or non-technical.

indicators.name: practice_platform_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting coding practice platform (LeetCode, HackerRank, Exercism, Project Euler, Codewars, Advent of Code) or competitive programming resource. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: work_focused_entry
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this entry is work or learning focused (technical content, documentation, professional resources). 0 if distraction (entertainment, social media, unrelated browsing, shopping).

indicators.name: scattered_search_indicator
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this is a quick tangential lookup unrelated to technical work (random curiosity, quick distraction, checking something personal). 0 if part of focused technical work session.

indicators.name: mental_health_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to mental health concerns (depression, anxiety, therapy, counseling, mood disorders, mental health treatments like ketamine for depression). 0 otherwise. Presence indicates lower wellbeing.

indicators.name: positive_leisure_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if entry shows positive leisure (music, travel planning, hobbies, entertainment, restaurants, recreational activities). 0 if work-focused, problem-searching, or health-concern related.

indicators.name: sleep_concern_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to sleep problems (insomnia, sleep tracking apps like Oura, sleep improvement, 'can't sleep', sleep disorders). 0 otherwise. Presence suggests sleep issues.

indicators.name: late_night_entry
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if timestamp is between midnight (00:00) and 5:00 AM local time. 0 otherwise. Indicates activity during typical sleep hours.

indicators.name: stress_burnout_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search explicitly mentions work stress, burnout, overwhelm, exhaustion, need for vacation, work-life balance, 'hate my job'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: urgent_problem_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search shows urgency or frustration (contains 'urgent', 'ASAP', 'not working', 'help', multiple question marks, all caps, error codes suggesting production issues). 0 for calm exploratory searches.

indicators.name: peer_comparison_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search involves comparing to others (developer salary comparisons, 'how good should I be', skill level expectations, 'average engineer', comparing career trajectories). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: other_developer_profile_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting another developer's profile (GitHub profiles, LinkedIn of engineers, researcher pages, prominent developer blogs/portfolios). 0 for own profiles or non-profile pages.

indicators.name: topic_complexity
indicators.how_to_measure: Ordinal 1-5: Rate technical complexity. 1=trivial (basic syntax), 2=simple (standard implementation), 3=moderate (design patterns, APIs), 4=advanced (cryptography, distributed systems, type theory), 5=cutting-edge (research papers, novel algorithms).

indicators.name: specialized_domain_exploration
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if exploring specialized/niche technical area (hardware security, formal verification, category theory, consensus protocols, PUFs). 0 for general-purpose programming topics.

indicators.name: exploratory_tangent
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search shows freedom to explore tangentially (curiosity-driven lookups, 'what is X', exploring related concepts without apparent pressure). 0 if strictly task-necessary searching.

indicators.name: help_forum_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting help forums where one might ask questions (Stack Overflow, Reddit programming subs, Discord tech servers, community forums). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: collaboration_tool_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting team collaboration tools (Slack, Teams, GitHub PR discussions, shared docs, Jira, project management tools). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: developer_community_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting developer community spaces (Hacker News, Reddit tech communities, Dev.to, tech Discord, IRC channels, mailing lists). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: engineering_culture_engagement
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if engaging with engineering culture (tech news, engineering blogs, conference talks, podcast content, industry discussions, tech company news). 0 for pure reference material or non-tech.

indicators.name: career_development_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to engineering career (skill roadmaps, career paths, 'senior engineer requirements', job searching, professional growth, tech interviews). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: self_directed_entry
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if entry appears self-directed (personal interest topics, curiosity-driven exploration, learning by choice, side projects). 0 if appears task-assigned (specific work errors, required documentation, assigned technology).

indicators.name: exploration_category
indicators.how_to_measure: Categorical: Classify entry purpose. Options: 'required_task' (clearly work-assigned), 'skill_building' (learning for work), 'curiosity' (personal interest), 'personal' (non-work), 'unclear'. Choose best fit.

indicators.name: safety_anxiety_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for neuroticism: Binary: 1 if search relates to anxiety about safety, fear management, or obsessive risk-checking (fear of flying resources like 'flying with confidence', checking plane crash news, airline safety ratings, disaster statistics, seeking reassurance about risks). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: mood_treatment_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for neuroticism: Binary: 1 if searching for mood disorder treatments, depression interventions, or experimental psychiatric treatments (ketamine for depression, therapeutic approaches for anxiety/depression, specific medication side effects for psychiatric drugs). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: conceptual_why_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for growth_orientation: Binary: 1 if search explicitly asks 'why' something works or seeks theoretical/conceptual understanding rather than procedural 'how to' (e.g., 'why do we need monads', 'why haskell io pure', 'why isnt haskell more popular', 'why X designed this way'). 0 for purely procedural or non-technical searches.

indicators.name: challenging_paradigm_persistence
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for growth_orientation: Binary: 1 if entry is part of a sustained learning session on fundamentally challenging concepts (functional programming concepts like monads/functors/applicatives, type theory, category theory - topics that require paradigm shift thinking). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: beginner_tutorial_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for years_of_experience: Binary: 1 if search explicitly seeks beginner/introductory content for fundamental programming concepts ('learn programming', 'python for beginners', 'introduction to coding', 'first steps in X'). 0 otherwise. NOTE: Presence suggests LESS experience (inverse proxy).

indicators.name: system_configuration_expertise
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for years_of_experience: Binary: 1 if search involves advanced system/environment configuration that requires prior experience (Linux kernel parameters, fingerprint driver installation, specific hardware compatibility on Linux, cross-generation hardware knowledge like X1 Carbon gen 6/7/9). 0 for basic usage questions.
